title.narrative: Gränsöverskridande dialog för fred i Stora sjöregionen
Trans-border Dialogue for Peace in the Great Lakes Region

description.narrative: Programmet syftar till att möjliggöra utökad dialog mellan fredsaktörer i Rwanda, Burundi och DR Kongo. Det övergripande målet är att genom samverkan mellan olika befolkningsgrupper och beslutsfattare i Stora sjöområdet skapa fred och sammanhållning i regionen. Partnerorganisationen Interpeace inkom i maj 2014 med ett förslag till den svenska ambassaden gällande en utökad budget om SEK 15 640 000 som ett tillägg till det ursprungliga avtalet mellan Sverige och Interpeace (beslut KIG P 22/13). Genom det här beslutet kommer Sverige att stödja programmet med totalt SEK 42 040 000, vilket är 68% av den totala programbudgeten.

The aim of the programme is to enable a dialogue between peacemakers in Rwanda, Burundi and DR Congo. The overall objective is to achieve peace and social cohesion through collaboration and inter-cooperation among and between diverse populations and decision makers in the Great Lakes region. Interpeace, the partner organization, submitted a proposal to the Swedish Embassy in May 2014 with an increased budget of SEK 15 640 000 as an amendment to the original agreement between Sweden and Interpeace (decision KIG P 22/13). Sweden will with this decision support the programme with SEK 42 040 000 in total, which is 68% of the total programme budget.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2016Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: (Summary related to the whole programme)
Phase one of this Trans-Border Dialogue for Peace programme has been designed to influence and contribute to behavioural change among four boundary partners: 1) Decision Makers, 2) CSOs, 3) Community Members and 4) Regional Organizations. Overall, across these four boundary partners, the programme engaged approximately 16,024 people, of whom, 40% were women and 50% were youth below the age of 30. These actors were engaged by the programmes’ five core strategies (research, dialogue, advocacy, collaboration with CSOs and media outreach) through which the programme changed their behaviour so that they could serve as catalysts for positive change towards a peaceful Great Lakes Region.
The programme has witnessed the following changes among the programme’s four boundary partners, expected and unexpected, that relate to the intended outcome: 1) Decision makers now accept and support the programme after a few initial engagements to gain their trust and allay their suspicions and concerns. Decision makers engaged in the programme have been transformed to using dialogue, meeting citizens and collaborating for regional peace; 2) CSOs use participatory methods to convey populations’ needs to authorities and to collaborate with other CSOs across borders; 3) Community members participated profoundly in the programme’s activities, and have transformed relationships of mistrust into collaborative cross-border relationships through dialogue and utilized dialogue to engage decision makers directly; and 4) Regional organizations have agreed to formally partner with the programme to promote regional peace, they have actively collaborated with the programme and agreed to the use of the programme’s participatory approach.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
